The McCarran: Walter Act of 1952 does not mention religion nor Muslims, as stated by the U.S. State Department Office of the Historian.
The act was primarily focused on immigra: aiming to limit who could come to the United States based on various factors such as skill sets and family reunification.
The act introduced a quota system for im: admitting people of different nationalities at a rate of one-sixth of 1 percent of the number of immigrants from a country living in the United States in 1920.
The claim that the McCarran: Walter Act of 1952 bans Muslims from holding public office in the United States is incorrect, as confirmed by fact-checkers and experts.
